data.title: Input States
data.body:
Hi,
I have written this in the forum already. It would be great to have a finer differentiation between input states. I would recommentd something like this.

Input released(0)
Input just pressed(1)
Input pressed(2)
Input just released(3)

I have written a custom helper class for my project which does exactly what I mentioned above! Here is the code.

```
### Custom Input Class
class input_states:
    var input_name
    var prev_state
    var current_state
    var input
    var output_state

    ### Get the input name and store it
    func _init(var input_name):
        self.input_name = input_name

    ### check the input and compare it with previous states
    func check():
        self.input = Input.is_action_pressed(self.input_name)

        self.prev_state = self.current_state
        self.current_state = self.input

        if not prev_state and not current_state:
            self.output_state = 0 ### Released
        elif not prev_state and current_state:
            self.output_state = 1 ### Just Pressed
        elif prev_state and current_state:
            self.output_state = 2 ### Pressed
        elif prev_state and not current_state:
            self.output_state = 3 ### Just Released

        return self.output_state

### get input
var move_left = input_states.new("ui_left")

### how it works
func _process(delta):
    if move_left.check() == 1:
        print("just pressed")
```

data.title: can't edit local SpriteFrames (even from Animation Editor)
data.body:
What is the proper way to access local SpriteFrames (saved in the scene, rather than saved individually as .res/.xml files) for editing? (ie: Path is either clear or says something like res://robot.scn::0).

The Load dialog only wants to load a res/xml file, not resources stored in the scene.
I had thought maybe the ones I used in animations could be accessed from the Animation Editor... However, the button my mouse is over in the image below does nothing.

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/17898384/godot04.jpg

I suspect it should open up the SpriteFrames for editing. Even if it did as expected, clicking on the v (down arrow) icon and choosing Load won't allow me to access other SpriteFrames stored in the scene...

**tl;dr** - I don't know how to see all of the local SpriteFrames resources in a scene (nor how to load them into an AnimatedSprite or key them into an AnimationPlayer). And I think that button in the pic is broken.

data.title: Fixed OS X retina initial videomode size
data.body:
OSX current_videomode size is now initialized with correct resolution based on backing store. Fixes issue where content does not correctly fit in windows on retina displays when first drawn (before this change, it was necessary to resize a window to get the videomode size to be correct). This issue was prevalent on my 15in MBPr 2012, running Mavericks 10.9.1, on the discrete card.

@solgar posted an image of what this fixes in issue #20.

data.title: Fix #113 editor_settings.xml corruption
data.body:
In the `parse_tag` method of the `class ResourceInteractiveLoaderXML`,
the class responsible of loading the editor_settings.xml file, the
properties' values are loaded directly into an `String` object but the
file contents are always UTF-8, which leads to garbage in the XML file
when saved.

This patch reads the properties' values in a `CharString` and translate
them to UTF-8.

Tested on Archlinux x86_64.
To test, please try to reproduce the issue #113.

data.title: armature node for 2D cut-out animation
data.body:
Hope someone pickup this feature request!

It is a little hard to animate a 2D cut-out sprite without bones and constrains, ndee from the Godot forum [suggested](http://www.godotengine.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=111&p=555#p523) implementing many functionalities that exists on Spine (a 2D skeletal animation for games).

I think that the teaser of the Spine software could give ideas of how and what to implement into Godot to make animation more easier, [watch the video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=avMYAKvSqYM).

data.title: Need a CONTRIBUTING.md
data.body:
A CONTRIBUTING.md file is very useful because it spells out how someone can and should contribute to your project. It also appears as a link above every pull request and issue so that common questions can be answered. Here's some  examples of a CONTRIBUTING.md file: https://github.com/mozilla/localForage/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
https://github.com/mozilla/webmaker.org/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
https://github.com/photonstorm/phaser/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

data.title: Win32 tools=no build mangles system library names
data.body:
When compiling with:

```
scons bin/godot.exe tools=no
```

The build fails during the final link with:

```
LINK : fatal error LNK1181: cannot open input file 'winmm.nt.lib'
```

The problem is this block at line 69 in _platform/windows/detect.py_, which is inadvertently adding the _LIBSUFFIX_ to system libraries.

``` python
    if (env["tools"]=="no"):
        #no tools suffix
        env['OBJSUFFIX'] = ".nt"+env['OBJSUFFIX']
        env['LIBSUFFIX'] = ".nt"+env['LIBSUFFIX']
```

Removing that block will complicate keeping both a no-tools and an editor build in the same directory but I am not familiar enough with scons to know how to work around the issue.

data.title: Fix #19 Can't open project (with non-ASCII path)
data.body:
In `class OS_Unix` the arguments in the `execute` method are converted
to UTF-8, but in the `main` program's method they're inserted into a
wide-char `Vector` before translating them from UTF-8 and thus the
non-ASCII characters are lost.

This fix converts the `argv` elements to UTF-8 using `String::utf8`
before inserting them in the `Vector`.

Tested in Archlinux x86_64.

Please test this change in Windows with a non-UTF-8 encoding (e.g. ISO-8859-15), it may break Windows-only behavior because the `execute` method in `class OS_Windows` doesn't convert the arguments to UTF-8.

data.title: editor_settings.xml corruption when creating projects with non-ascii characters
data.body:
When a project with a path with non-ascii characters exists in the project's list, the next time the project manager is opened and closed some garbage is added in the editor_settings.xml file in the `name` property of the project's `string` tag, just after every non-ascii character in the path.
Only the `name` property is corrupted, not the tag's value, although it also contains the project's path.

Every time the project manager is opened and closed the garbage is doubled and, sometimes, can fail to open editor_settings.xml file at all, showing this error output:

```
ERROR: open: Not a XML:UTF-8 File: /home/terseus/.godot/editor_settings.xml
   At: core/io/resource_format_xml.cpp:1594.
ERROR: load: Condition ' err!=OK ' is true. returned: RES()
   At: core/io/resource_loader.cpp:135.
ERROR: load: Failed loading resource: /home/terseus/.godot/editor_settings.xml
   At: core/io/resource_loader.cpp:203.
ERROR: create: Could not open config file.
   At: tools/editor/editor_settings.cpp:242.
```

Steps to reproduce (beware, make a backup of editor_settings.xml first):
1. Create a project with a path that contains any non-ascii character (e.g. é).
2. Close the project manager.
3. Open the file editor_settings.xml, there will be a new `<string name="projects/">` with the newly created project; notice that there is no corruption now.
4. Open the project manager, then close it again.
5. Open the file editor_settings.xml again, the project's entry now will contain some garbage.
6. Open and close again the project manager.
7. Open the file again, now there will be (more or less) double the garbage.

Repeating step 6 will double the garbage in the config file.
As a side note, after 20 repetitions my editor_settings.xml file grow past 2MiB.
Also note that the project doesn't need to be opened at all to trigger the bug, just to exist in the project list.

Tested on Archlinux x86_64, build from git.

data.title: Image loader should disable repeat by default
Removal of obsolete editor plugins Fixes #64
data.body:
The FontEditorPlugin and the AnimationEditorPlugins are no longer used and can be removed.

Fixes Issue #64

data.title: Fix for Issue #108
data.body:
Entering a somethign in the 'Path field' triggers the
`_path_changed` signal being triggered.
This in turn calls Globals::localize_path(const String& p_path) with the
currently entered string.
localize_path then is replacing backslashes with slashes and calls
afterwards `String::simplify_path`

String::simplify_path is checking wheter a string starts with:
- res://
- local://
- user://

If any of those is true it removes this section.

However, if any of the first letters of those are matching begins_with
returns true, which is wrong. It should only return true if the whole
string is matched at the beginning.

This caused the whole desaster and lead localize_path into an endless loop
because out of `u` suddenly became user:// which it then tried again to
localize and so on.

This fix, fixes the root of the problem which is begins_with which should
not return true if not the whole search string was matched.

Signed-off-by: Vinzenz Feenstra evilissimo@gmail.com

data.title: Application crashes when creating script with path beginning with 'u' or 'l'
data.body:
The application crashes when entering a path beginning with 'u' or 'l' in the create script dialog. This happens only with a lower case 'u' or 'l' if it is the first character entered. There is no message printed to the terminal when the crash happens. Entering 'u' or 'l' when there are already other characters in the field works fine. This seems to be the only field that does this. All other fields work fine.

Running godot_x11.64 in Ubuntu 12.10. Version 4066.

Steps to reproduce:
- Create new project. 
- Add a node (I've tested with Control, Label and Button).
- Click the "Edit/Create the Node Script" button.
- The "Create Script for Node.." dialog appears.
- In the "Path field", press 'u' or 'l'.

Also, in case it's relevant, here's the terminal output from running ./godot_x11.64. This is the output printed when godot engine starts, whether the application crashes or not.

```
opening pack (workingdir)/godot_x11.64, -1, -1
opening pack (workingdir)/data.pck, -1, -1
ERROR: set_custom_property_info: Condition ' !props.has(p_prop) ' is true.
   At: core/globals.cpp:1320.
***** SET ICON ***** 128  128
ERROR: set_stylebox: Condition ' p_style.is_null() ' is true.
   At: scene/resources/theme.cpp:267.
editor: 0
list diring on: ~/.godot/plugins
OPENING: (workingdir)/a (a)
ERROR: set_custom_property_info: Condition ' !props.has(p_prop) ' is true.
   At: core/globals.cpp:1320.
***** SET ICON ***** 128  128
ERROR: set_stylebox: Condition ' p_style.is_null() ' is true.
   At: scene/resources/theme.cpp:267.
editor: 1
list diring on: ~/.godot/plugins
ERROR: add_child: Can't add child, already has a parent
   At: scene/main/node.cpp:551.
ERROR: add_signal: Type already has signal
   At: core/object_type_db.cpp:412.
initial sources changed: 0
SCAN BEGIN!
sources changed: 0
```

data.title: Windows StreamPeerWinsock::set_nodelay implementation
data.body: The Windows implementation of StreamPeer left set_nodelay() as a no-op.  The code from the POSIX implementation is also correct on Windows so this patch just copies that code.

But since github does not support pull request of wiki. It have to manually pull and merge by godot repository's collaborator.

data.title: get_viewport_rect() is undocumented
data.body: get_viewport_rect() is used in Pong Tutorial, but I can't find it in documentation on wiki or in "help".

data.title: Clarify the license for the Demos
data.body:
Even though the godot engine is released under the MIT license, it is currently currently an open question under which license the files in the `demo` folder are licensed. (Including the assets)

This is good to know for redistribution in sense of packaging for linux distributions if it can be included or not. Also if someone would like to create an installer for Windows or any other kind of redistribution.

Thanks.

data.title: LICENSE or COPYING file should be included
data.body:
Please add into the root of the project a LICENSE or COPYING file containing the MIT license to make it clear that the code is licensed under the MIT license.

This is a common practice for open source projects.

data.title: Firefox freeze on open html5-exported game
data.body:
Hello. 

I exported Pong example as html5 game and tried to open it with Firefox Web-browser. 
Firefox freeze on start for a few minutes. When it "unfreeze" game doesn't start. Only gray screen and errors in output field.

Steps to reproduce:
- Open Pong 2D example in Godot
- Export as html5-game
- Open exported game in Firefox
